title: Apr 05, 2025
text:
Yiming Teng


’t Hooft Anomaly



In this lecture, we discussed how quantum anomalies manifest at the perturbative level. We outlined the method of computing chiral anomalies using the AVV one-loop triangle diagram and highlighted the connection between anomalies and regularization schemes. Based on the triangle diagram, we demonstrated the conditions required for perturbative gauge anomaly cancellation in chiral gauge theories and introduced the concept of ’t Hooft anomalies for global symmetries. Finally, we briefly mentioned the existence of non-perturbative anomalies in SU(2) chiral gauge theories, which cannot be detected via perturbative methods.



Video 2025-04-05



/

Gauge Theory (David Tong)
Characteristic Forms and Geometric Invariants (Shiing-Shen Chern, James Simons)
Topological Gauge Theories and Group Cohomology (Robbert Dijkgraaf, Edward Witten)
Symmetry Protected Topological Orders and the Group Cohomology of their Symmetry Group (Xie Chen, Zheng-Cheng Gu, Zheng-Xin Liu, and Xiao-Gang Wen)

title: Apr 12, 2025
text:
Chen Wei


Homology Theory



In this lecture, we introduced the definitions and basic properties of homology groups. We presented two approaches to defining homology and proved their equivalence. Along the way, we also discussed the concept of chain complexes.



Video 2025-04-12



/

title: May 24, 2025
text:
Xingyu Chen


Instanton



We begin by introducing the concept of instantons through an analysis of transition amplitudes in perturbative classical field theory. By employing a Wick rotation to Euclidean time, we examine the Euclidean action and corresponding equations of motion to motivate the necessity and role of instantons. We then perform explicit analyses and computations in three specific cases—the single-well, double-well, and periodic potentials—to illustrate how instanton techniques are applied in practice.



Video 2025-05-24



Notes 2025-05-24




Aspects of Symmetry (S. Coleman)

title: May 10, 2025
text:
Yicheng Zhou


Topological K-theory



We began by focusing on topological K-theory for topological spaces, aiming to clarify its foundational concepts and derive several essential properties. We then explored algebraic K-theory for \(C^*\)-algebras and compared it with topological K-theory through concrete examples. Finally, we introduced the notion of “spectrum–algebra correspondence” to establish an intuitive connection between the two theories.



Video 2025-05-10



Notes 2025-05-10




K-Theory and Elliptic Operators (Gregory D. Landweber)

title: May 06, 2025
text:
Yiming Teng


Wess-Zumino Condition



We began by discussing gauge anomalies in chiral gauge theories and introduced the Wess–Zumino consistency condition as a constraint on admissible anomalies. This condition was then reformulated using the BRST operator, providing a cohomological perspective. Next, we introduced the descent equations and constructed anomaly terms in even-dimensional spacetimes by descending from higher-dimensional Chern characters, ensuring compatibility with the Wess–Zumino condition. This led to the establishment of a deep connection between chiral fermion theories on even-dimensional boundaries and Chern–Simons theories in the bulk.



Video 2025-05-06



Notes 2025-05-06




The Structure of Gauge and Gravitational Anomalies (Luis Álvarez-Gaumé, Paul H. Ginsparg)
Geometry, Topology and Physics (Mikio Nakahara)

title: Jul 20, 2025
text:
Yiyi Wan


Quantizable Condition and Maslov Technique



In this lecture, we built upon the symplectic geometry discussed last time to examine the quantization condition for projectable Lagrangian submanifolds. Then, for general Lagrangian submanifolds, we introduced the prequantum _{} bundle and established the geometric condition under which such submanifolds are prequantizable. To determine whether a prequantizable Lagrangian submanifold is further quantizable, we employed the Maslov technique. As an example, we provided the exact Maslov quantization condition in the case where the Lagrangian submanifold is a circle. More general cases will be discussed in future sessions.



Video 2025-07-20



Notes 2025-07-20




Lectures on the Geometry of Quantization (Sean Bates, Alan Weinstein)

title: Aug 09, 2025
text:
Yuxiao Xie


Introduction to 2d Conformal Field Theory



The purpose of this talk is to interpret the main ingredients of two-dimensional Euclidean conformal field theory in terms of path integrals, including states, fields, the state-field correspondence, the Virasoro algebra, and operator product expansions. This led us to Segal’s axiomatization of conformal field theory, which defines a conformal field theory as a projective functor from the cobordism category of Riemann surfaces to the category of Hilbert spaces, whence the conformal bootstrap is understood as a consequence of the gluing axiom. This perspective has the advantage of elucidating the link between conformal field theory and conformal geometry—especially with Teichmüller theory—and, in the case of Liouville theory, it has recently been given a mathematically rigorous construction.



Video 2025-08-09



共形场论的 Segal 公理化 (谢雨潇)




Conformal Bootstrap in Liouville Theory (Colin Guillarmou, Antti Kupiainen, Rémi Rhodes, Vincent Vargas)
Polyakov’s Formulation of 2d Bosonic String Theory (Colin Guillarmou, Rémi Rhodes, Vincent Vargas)
Segal’s Axioms and Bootstrap for Liouville Theory (Colin Guillarmou, Antti Kupiainen, Rémi Rhodes, Vincent Vargas)
The Definition of Conformal Field Theory (Graeme Segal)

title: Jul 26, 2025
text:
Yiyi Wan


A Complete Geometric Characterization of Quantizability



In this discussion, following the Maslov technique introduced previously, we defined Morse families that generate Lagrangian submanifolds, as well as the Maslov principal bundle and Maslov line bundle. We then explored a key property of Morse families in geometric quantization: their existence and stable equivalence. After accounting for Maslov quantum corrections, we introduced the notion of a phase bundle and established a geometric criterion for quantizability—the existence of a non-vanishing parallel section of the phase bundle. This parallels the condition for prequantizability, which requires a non-vanishing parallel section of the prequantum line bundle. We thus gave a complete characterization of quantizability of an arbitrary Lagrangian submanifold. Finally, we concluded by illustrating the geometric correspondence between the classical and quantum worlds.



Video 2025-07-26



Notes 2025-07-26




Lectures on the Geometry of Quantization (Sean Bates, Alan Weinstein)

title: Mar 22, 2025
text:
Yiming Teng


Basic Concepts of Higher-form Symmetries



Starting from the Ward identity, we rephrased several well-known results using differential forms and topological operators. This reformulation helped highlight the key structural features required for generalizing to higher-form symmetries.

text:

title: Math-Physics Paris
text: Supervised by Juven, the Math-Physics Paris Seminar focuses on symmetries in modern physics, exploring their fundamental roles and recent developments across CMT, HEP and mathematical physics. This seminar aligns with the theme of the 2024 IHES Summer School.

title: Topological Quantum Dark Matter via Global Anomaly Cancellation
text:
Juven Wang


Standard Model (SM) with 15 Weyl fermions per family (lacking the 16th, the sterile right-handed neutrino \(\nu_R\)) suffers from mixed gauge-gravitational anomalies tied to baryon number plus or minus lepton number \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) symmetry. Including \(\nu_R\) per family can cancel these anomalies, but when \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) symmetry is preserved as discrete finite subgroups rather than a continuous U(1), the perturbative local anomalies become nonperturbative global anomalies. In this work, we systematically enumerate these gauge-gravitational global anomalies involving discrete \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) that are enhanced from the fermion parity \(\mathbb{Z}_2^\mathrm{F}\) to \(\mathbb{Z}_{2N}^\mathrm{F}\), with \(N = 2, 3, 4, 6, 9\), etc. The discreteness of \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) is constrained by multi-fermion deformations beyond-the-SM and the family number \(N_f\). Unlike the free quadratic \(\nu_R\) Majorana mass gap preserving the minimal \(\mathbb{Z}_2^\mathrm{F}\), we explore novel scenarios canceling \((\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L})\)-gravitational anomalies while preserving the \(\mathbb{Z}_{2N}^\mathrm{F}\) discrete symmetries, featuring 4-dimensional interacting gapped topological orders (potentially with or without low-energy topological quantum field theory descriptions) or gapless sectors (e.g., conformal field theories). We propose symmetric anomalous sectors as quantum dark matter to cancel SM’s global anomalies. We find the uniqueness of the family number at \(N_f = 3\), such that when the representation of \(\mathbb{Z}_{2N}^\mathrm{F}\) from the faithful \(\mathbf{B} + \mathbf{L}\) for baryons at \(N = N_c = 3\) is extended to the faithful \(\mathbf{Q} + N_c \mathbf{L}\) for quarks at \(N = N_c N_f = 9\), this symmetry extension \(\mathbb{Z}_{N_c=3} \to \mathbb{Z}_{N_c N_f=9} \to \mathbb{Z}_{N_f=3}\) matches with the topological order dark matter construction. Key implications include: (1) a 5th force mediating between SM and dark matter via discrete \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) gauge fields, (2) dark matter as topological order quantum matter with gapped anyon excitations at ends of extended defects, and (3) Ultra Unification and topological leptogenesis.



Topological Quantum Dark Matter via Global Anomaly Cancellation (Juven Wang)

title: Topological Quantum Dark Matter via Global Anomaly Cancellation
text:
Juven Wang


Standard Model (SM) with 15 Weyl fermions per family (lacking the 16th, the sterile right-handed neutrino \(\nu_R\)) suffers from mixed gauge-gravitational anomalies tied to baryon number plus or minus lepton number \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) symmetry. Including \(\nu_R\) per family can cancel these anomalies, but when \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) symmetry is preserved as discrete finite subgroups rather than a continuous U(1), the perturbative local anomalies become nonperturbative global anomalies. In this work, we systematically enumerate these gauge-gravitational global anomalies involving discrete \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) that are enhanced from the fermion parity \(\mathbb{Z}_2^\mathrm{F}\) to \(\mathbb{Z}_{2N}^\mathrm{F}\), with \(N = 2, 3, 4, 6, 9\), etc. The discreteness of \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) is constrained by multi-fermion deformations beyond-the-SM and the family number \(N_f\). Unlike the free quadratic \(\nu_R\) Majorana mass gap preserving the minimal \(\mathbb{Z}_2^\mathrm{F}\), we explore novel scenarios canceling \((\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L})\)-gravitational anomalies while preserving the \(\mathbb{Z}_{2N}^\mathrm{F}\) discrete symmetries, featuring 4-dimensional interacting gapped topological orders (potentially with or without low-energy topological quantum field theory descriptions) or gapless sectors (e.g., conformal field theories). We propose symmetric anomalous sectors as quantum dark matter to cancel SM’s global anomalies. We find the uniqueness of the family number at \(N_f = 3\), such that when the representation of \(\mathbb{Z}_{2N}^\mathrm{F}\) from the faithful \(\mathbf{B} + \mathbf{L}\) for baryons at \(N = N_c = 3\) is extended to the faithful \(\mathbf{Q} + N_c \mathbf{L}\) for quarks at \(N = N_c N_f = 9\), this symmetry extension \(\mathbb{Z}_{N_c=3} \to \mathbb{Z}_{N_c N_f=9} \to \mathbb{Z}_{N_f=3}\) matches with the topological order dark matter construction. Key implications include: (1) a 5th force mediating between SM and dark matter via discrete \(\mathbf{B} \pm \mathbf{L}\) gauge fields, (2) dark matter as topological order quantum matter with gapped anyon excitations at ends of extended defects, and (3) Ultra Unification and topological leptogenesis.



Topological Quantum Dark Matter via Global Anomaly Cancellation (Juven Wang)

title: Anomaly Inflow and the η-Invariant
text:
Edward Witten, Kazuya Yonekura


Perturbative fermion anomalies in spacetime dimension \(d\) have a well-known relation to Chern–Simons functions in dimension \(D = d + 1\). This relationship is manifested in a beautiful way in ``anomaly inflow’’ from the bulk of a system to its boundary. Along with perturbative anomalies, fermions also have global or nonperturbative anomalies, which can be incorporated by using the \(\eta\)-invariant of Atiyah, Patodi, and Singer instead of the Chern–Simons function. Here we give a nonperturbative description of anomaly inflow, involving the \(\eta\)-invariant. This formula has been expected in the past based on the Dai–Freed theorem, but has not been fully justified. It leads to a general description of perturbative and nonperturbative fermion anomalies in \(d\) dimensions in terms of an \(\eta\)-invariant in \(D\) dimensions. This \(\eta\)-invariant is a cobordism invariant whenever perturbative anomalies cancel.



Anomaly Inflow and the η-Invariant (Edward Witten, Kazuya Yonekura)

title: Anomaly Inflow and the η-Invariant
text:
Edward Witten, Kazuya Yonekura


Perturbative fermion anomalies in spacetime dimension \(d\) have a well-known relation to Chern–Simons functions in dimension \(D = d + 1\). This relationship is manifested in a beautiful way in ``anomaly inflow’’ from the bulk of a system to its boundary. Along with perturbative anomalies, fermions also have global or nonperturbative anomalies, which can be incorporated by using the \(\eta\)-invariant of Atiyah, Patodi, and Singer instead of the Chern–Simons function. Here we give a nonperturbative description of anomaly inflow, involving the \(\eta\)-invariant. This formula has been expected in the past based on the Dai–Freed theorem, but has not been fully justified. It leads to a general description of perturbative and nonperturbative fermion anomalies in \(d\) dimensions in terms of an \(\eta\)-invariant in \(D\) dimensions. This \(\eta\)-invariant is a cobordism invariant whenever perturbative anomalies cancel.



Anomaly Inflow and the η-Invariant (Edward Witten, Kazuya Yonekura)

title: The Index of Elliptic Operators II
text:
M. F. Atiyah, G. B. Segal


The purpose of this paper is to show how the index theorem of [5] can be reformulated as a general “Lefschetz fixed-point theorem” on the lines of [2]. In this way we shall obtain the main theorem of [2], generalized to deal with arbitrary fixed-point sets, but only for transformations belonging to a compact group.
The content of this paper is essentially topological, and it should be viewed as a paper on the equivariant \(K\)-theory of manifolds. The analysis has all been done in [5], and what we do here is simply to express the topological index in terms of fixed-point sets. This is quite independent of the main theorem of [5] asserting the equality of the topological and analytical indices.
As in [5], we avoid cohomology and use only \(K\)-theory. In paper III of this series, we shall pass over to cohomology obtaining explicit formulas in terms of characteristic classes.
The basic result in \(K_G\)-theory which leads to the fixed-point formula is what we call the Localization Theorem. We review this in 1. In 2, this is then applied to the topological index. Some cases of special interest are then discussed in 3.



The Index of Elliptic Operators II (M. F. Atiyah, G. B. Segal)

title: The Index of Elliptic Operators II
text:
M. F. Atiyah, G. B. Segal


The purpose of this paper is to show how the index theorem of [5] can be reformulated as a general “Lefschetz fixed-point theorem” on the lines of [2]. In this way we shall obtain the main theorem of [2], generalized to deal with arbitrary fixed-point sets, but only for transformations belonging to a compact group.
The content of this paper is essentially topological, and it should be viewed as a paper on the equivariant \(K\)-theory of manifolds. The analysis has all been done in [5], and what we do here is simply to express the topological index in terms of fixed-point sets. This is quite independent of the main theorem of [5] asserting the equality of the topological and analytical indices.
As in [5], we avoid cohomology and use only \(K\)-theory. In paper III of this series, we shall pass over to cohomology obtaining explicit formulas in terms of characteristic classes.
The basic result in \(K_G\)-theory which leads to the fixed-point formula is what we call the Localization Theorem. We review this in 1. In 2, this is then applied to the topological index. Some cases of special interest are then discussed in 3.



The Index of Elliptic Operators II (M. F. Atiyah, G. B. Segal)

title: Introduction To Chern-Simons Theories
text:
Gregory W. Moore


These are lecture notes for a series of talks at the 2019 TASI school. They contain introductory material to the general subject of Chern-Simons theory. They are meant to be elementary and pedagogical. These notes are still in Preparation. Constructive comments are very welcome. (In particular, I have not been systematic about trying to include references. The literature is huge and I know my own work best. I will certainly be interested if people bring reference omissions to my attention.)



Introduction To Chern-Simons Theories (Gregory W. Moore)

title: The Atiyah-Singer Index Theorem
text:
Daniel S. Freed


The Atiyah-Singer index theorem, a landmark achievement of the early 1960s, brings together ideas in analysis, geometry, and topology. We recount some antecedents and motivations; various forms of the theorem; and some of its implications, which extend to the present.



The Atiyah-Singer Index Theorem (Daniel S. Freed)

title: The Atiyah-Singer Index Theorem
text:
Daniel S. Freed


The Atiyah-Singer index theorem, a landmark achievement of the early 1960s, brings together ideas in analysis, geometry, and topology. We recount some antecedents and motivations; various forms of the theorem; and some of its implications, which extend to the present.



The Atiyah-Singer Index Theorem (Daniel S. Freed)

title: Notes
text: Waiting to be filled…

title: Dai-Freed Anomalies in Particle Physics
text:
Iñaki García-Etxebarria, Miguel Montero


Anomalies can be elegantly analyzed by means of the Dai–Freed theorem. In this framework it is natural to consider a refinement of traditional anomaly cancellation conditions, which sometimes leads to nontrivial extra constraints in the fermion spectrum. We analyze these more refined anomaly cancellation conditions in a variety of theories of physical interest, including the Standard Model and the \(SU(5)\) and \(Spin(10)\) GUTs, which we find to be anomaly free. Turning to discrete symmetries, we find that baryon triality has a \(\mathbb{Z}_9\) anomaly that only cancels if the number of generations is a multiple of 3. Assuming the existence of certain anomaly-free \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) symmetry we relate the fact that there are 16 fermions per generation of the Standard Model — including right-handed neutrinos — to anomalies under time-reversal of boundary states in four-dimensional topological superconductors. A similar relation exists for the MSSM, only this time involving the number of gauginos and Higgsinos, and it is non-trivially, and remarkably, satisfied for the \(SU(3) \times SU(2) \times U(1)\) gauge group with two Higgs doublets. We relate the constraints we find to the well-known Ibáñez–Ross ones, and discuss the dependence on UV data of the construction. Finally, we comment on the (non-)existence of K-theoretic \(\theta\) angles in four dimensions.



Dai-Freed Anomalies in Particle Physics (Iñaki García-Etxebarria, Miguel Montero)

title: Dai-Freed Anomalies in Particle Physics
text:
Iñaki García-Etxebarria, Miguel Montero


Anomalies can be elegantly analyzed by means of the Dai–Freed theorem. In this framework it is natural to consider a refinement of traditional anomaly cancellation conditions, which sometimes leads to nontrivial extra constraints in the fermion spectrum. We analyze these more refined anomaly cancellation conditions in a variety of theories of physical interest, including the Standard Model and the \(SU(5)\) and \(Spin(10)\) GUTs, which we find to be anomaly free. Turning to discrete symmetries, we find that baryon triality has a \(\mathbb{Z}_9\) anomaly that only cancels if the number of generations is a multiple of 3. Assuming the existence of certain anomaly-free \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) symmetry we relate the fact that there are 16 fermions per generation of the Standard Model — including right-handed neutrinos — to anomalies under time-reversal of boundary states in four-dimensional topological superconductors. A similar relation exists for the MSSM, only this time involving the number of gauginos and Higgsinos, and it is non-trivially, and remarkably, satisfied for the \(SU(3) \times SU(2) \times U(1)\) gauge group with two Higgs doublets. We relate the constraints we find to the well-known Ibáñez–Ross ones, and discuss the dependence on UV data of the construction. Finally, we comment on the (non-)existence of K-theoretic \(\theta\) angles in four dimensions.



Dai-Freed Anomalies in Particle Physics (Iñaki García-Etxebarria, Miguel Montero)

title: Anomaly of 4d Weyl Fermion with Discrete Charge
text:
Zheyan Wan


We derive the anomaly indices of 4d Weyl fermions with symmetry \(\mathrm{Spin} \times \mathbb{Z}_n\) and \(\mathrm{Spin} \times_{\mathbb{Z}_2} \mathbb{Z}_{2m}\) by reducing the continuous \(\mathrm{Spin} \times \mathrm{U}(1)\) and \(\mathrm{Spin}^c\) anomaly indices on five-dimensional manifolds to discrete sectors subject to flux quantization. We calculate the values of the 5d invertible theories on the corresponding manifold generators. We express the values of the 5d invertible theories on general manifolds in terms of their values on the manifold generators.



Anomaly of 4d Weyl Fermion with Discrete Charge (Zheyan Wan)

title: Anomaly of 4d Weyl Fermion with Discrete Charge
text:
Zheyan Wan


We derive the anomaly indices of 4d Weyl fermions with symmetry \(\mathrm{Spin} \times \mathbb{Z}_n\) and \(\mathrm{Spin} \times_{\mathbb{Z}_2} \mathbb{Z}_{2m}\) by reducing the continuous \(\mathrm{Spin} \times \mathrm{U}(1)\) and \(\mathrm{Spin}^c\) anomaly indices on five-dimensional manifolds to discrete sectors subject to flux quantization. We calculate the values of the 5d invertible theories on the corresponding manifold generators. We express the values of the 5d invertible theories on general manifolds in terms of their values on the manifold generators.



Anomaly of 4d Weyl Fermion with Discrete Charge (Zheyan Wan)

title: The Index of Elliptic Operators I
text:
M. F. Atiyah, I. M. Singer


This is the first of a series of papers which will be devoted to a study of the index of elliptic operators on compact manifolds. The main result was announced in [6] and, for manifolds with boundary, in [5]. The long delay between these announcements and the present paper is due to several factors. On the one hand, a fairly detailed exposition has already appeared in [14]. On the other hand, our original proof, reproduced with minor modifications in [14], had a number of drawbacks. In the first place the use of cobordism, and the computational checking associated with this, were not very enlightening. More seriously, however, the method of proof did not lend itself to certain natural generalizations of the problem where appropriate cobordism groups were not known. The reader who is familiar with the Riemann–Roch theorem will realize that our original proof of the index theorem was modelled closely on Hirzebruch’s proof of the Riemann–Roch theorem. Naturally enough we were led to look for a proof modelled more on that of Grothendieck. While we have not completely succeeded in this aim, we have at least found a proof which is much more natural, does not use cobordism, and lends itself therefore to generalization. In spirit, at least, it has much in common with Grothendieck’s approach.



The Index of Elliptic Operators I (M. F. Atiyah, I. M. Singer)

title: The Index of Elliptic Operators I
text:
M. F. Atiyah, I. M. Singer


This is the first of a series of papers which will be devoted to a study of the index of elliptic operators on compact manifolds. The main result was announced in [6] and, for manifolds with boundary, in [5]. The long delay between these announcements and the present paper is due to several factors. On the one hand, a fairly detailed exposition has already appeared in [14]. On the other hand, our original proof, reproduced with minor modifications in [14], had a number of drawbacks. In the first place the use of cobordism, and the computational checking associated with this, were not very enlightening. More seriously, however, the method of proof did not lend itself to certain natural generalizations of the problem where appropriate cobordism groups were not known. The reader who is familiar with the Riemann–Roch theorem will realize that our original proof of the index theorem was modelled closely on Hirzebruch’s proof of the Riemann–Roch theorem. Naturally enough we were led to look for a proof modelled more on that of Grothendieck. While we have not completely succeeded in this aim, we have at least found a proof which is much more natural, does not use cobordism, and lends itself therefore to generalization. In spirit, at least, it has much in common with Grothendieck’s approach.



The Index of Elliptic Operators I (M. F. Atiyah, I. M. Singer)

title: Dai-Freed Theorem and Topological Phases of Matter
text:
Kazuya Yonekura


We describe a physics derivation of theorems due to Dai and Freed about the Atiyah–Patodi–Singer eta-invariant which is important for anomalies and topological phases of matter. This is done by studying a massive fermion. The key role is played by the wave function of the ground state in the Hilbert space of the fermion in the large mass limit. The ground state takes values in the determinant line bundle and has nontrivial Berry phases which characterize the low energy topological phases.



Dai-Freed Theorem and Topological Phases of Matter (Kazuya Yonekura)

title: Dai-Freed Theorem and Topological Phases of Matter
text:
Kazuya Yonekura


We describe a physics derivation of theorems due to Dai and Freed about the Atiyah–Patodi–Singer eta-invariant which is important for anomalies and topological phases of matter. This is done by studying a massive fermion. The key role is played by the wave function of the ground state in the Hilbert space of the fermion in the large mass limit. The ground state takes values in the determinant line bundle and has nontrivial Berry phases which characterize the low energy topological phases.



Dai-Freed Theorem and Topological Phases of Matter (Kazuya Yonekura)

title: Categorical Symmetry of the Standard Model from Gravitational Anomaly
text:
Pavel Putrov, Juven Wang


In the Standard Model, some combination of the baryon \(\mathbf{B}\) and lepton \(\mathbf{L}\) number symmetry is free of mixed anomalies with strong and electroweak \(su(3) \times su(2) \times u(1)_{\tilde{Y}}\) gauge forces. However, it can still suffer from a mixed gravitational anomaly, hypothetically pertinent to leptogenesis in the very early universe. This happens when the total “sterile right-handed” neutrino number \(n_{\nu_R}\) is not equal to the family number \(N_f\). Thus the invertible \(\mathbf{B} - \mathbf{L}\) symmetry current conservation can be violated quantum mechanically by gravitational backgrounds such as gravitational instantons. In specific, we show that a noninvertible categorical \(\mathbf{B} - \mathbf{L}\) generalized symmetry still survives in gravitational backgrounds. In general, we propose a construction of noninvertible symmetry charge operators as topological defects derived from invertible anomalous symmetries that suffer from mixed gravitational anomalies. Examples include the perturbative local and nonperturbative global anomalies classified by \(\mathbb{Z}\) and \(\mathbb{Z}_{16}\) respectively. For this construction, we utilize the anomaly inflow bulk-boundary correspondence, the 4d Pontryagin class and the gravitational Chern-Simons 3-form, the 3d Witten–Reshetikhin–Turaev-type topological quantum field theory with a framing anomaly corresponding to a 2d rational conformal field theory with an appropriate rational chiral central charge, and the 4d \(\mathbb{Z}_4^{\mathrm{TF}}\)-time-reversal symmetric topological superconductor with 3d boundary topological order.



Categorical Symmetry of the Standard Model from Gravitational Anomaly (Pavel Putrov, Juven Wang)

title: Categorical Symmetry of the Standard Model from Gravitational Anomaly
text:
Pavel Putrov, Juven Wang


In the Standard Model, some combination of the baryon \(\mathbf{B}\) and lepton \(\mathbf{L}\) number symmetry is free of mixed anomalies with strong and electroweak \(su(3) \times su(2) \times u(1)_{\tilde{Y}}\) gauge forces. However, it can still suffer from a mixed gravitational anomaly, hypothetically pertinent to leptogenesis in the very early universe. This happens when the total “sterile right-handed” neutrino number \(n_{\nu_R}\) is not equal to the family number \(N_f\). Thus the invertible \(\mathbf{B} - \mathbf{L}\) symmetry current conservation can be violated quantum mechanically by gravitational backgrounds such as gravitational instantons. In specific, we show that a noninvertible categorical \(\mathbf{B} - \mathbf{L}\) generalized symmetry still survives in gravitational backgrounds. In general, we propose a construction of noninvertible symmetry charge operators as topological defects derived from invertible anomalous symmetries that suffer from mixed gravitational anomalies. Examples include the perturbative local and nonperturbative global anomalies classified by \(\mathbb{Z}\) and \(\mathbb{Z}_{16}\) respectively. For this construction, we utilize the anomaly inflow bulk-boundary correspondence, the 4d Pontryagin class and the gravitational Chern-Simons 3-form, the 3d Witten–Reshetikhin–Turaev-type topological quantum field theory with a framing anomaly corresponding to a 2d rational conformal field theory with an appropriate rational chiral central charge, and the 4d \(\mathbb{Z}_4^{\mathrm{TF}}\)-time-reversal symmetric topological superconductor with 3d boundary topological order.



Categorical Symmetry of the Standard Model from Gravitational Anomaly (Pavel Putrov, Juven Wang)

title: Discrete Gauge Anomalies Revisited
text:
Chang-Tse Hsieh


We revisit discrete gauge anomalies in chiral fermion theories in \(3+1\) dimensions. We focus on the case that the full symmetry group of fermions is \(\mathrm{Spin}(4) \times \mathbb{Z}_n\) or \((\mathrm{Spin}(4) \times \mathbb{Z}_{2m})/\mathbb{Z}_2\) with \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) being the diagonal \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) subgroup. The anomalies are determined by the consistency condition — based on the Dai-Freed theorem — of formulating a chiral fermion theory on a generic spacetime manifold with a structure associated with either one of the above symmetry groups and are represented by elements of some finite abelian groups. Accordingly, we give a reformulation of the anomaly cancellation conditions, and compare them with the previous result by Ibáñez and Ross. The role of symmetry extensions in discrete symmetry anomalies is clarified in a formal fashion. We also study gapped states of fermion with an anomalous global \(\mathbb{Z}_n\) symmetry, and present a model for constructing these states in the framework of weak coupling.



Discrete Gauge Anomalies Revisited (Chang-Tse Hsieh)

title: Discrete Gauge Anomalies Revisited
text:
Chang-Tse Hsieh


We revisit discrete gauge anomalies in chiral fermion theories in \(3+1\) dimensions. We focus on the case that the full symmetry group of fermions is \(\mathrm{Spin}(4) \times \mathbb{Z}_n\) or \((\mathrm{Spin}(4) \times \mathbb{Z}_{2m})/\mathbb{Z}_2\) with \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) being the diagonal \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) subgroup. The anomalies are determined by the consistency condition — based on the Dai-Freed theorem — of formulating a chiral fermion theory on a generic spacetime manifold with a structure associated with either one of the above symmetry groups and are represented by elements of some finite abelian groups. Accordingly, we give a reformulation of the anomaly cancellation conditions, and compare them with the previous result by Ibáñez and Ross. The role of symmetry extensions in discrete symmetry anomalies is clarified in a formal fashion. We also study gapped states of fermion with an anomalous global \(\mathbb{Z}_n\) symmetry, and present a model for constructing these states in the framework of weak coupling.



Discrete Gauge Anomalies Revisited (Chang-Tse Hsieh)

title: Puzzles
text: Anomalies

title: Aug 02, 2025
text:
Chen Wei


Differential Operators on Manifolds



This lecture, based on Chapter 1 of Christian Bär’s Spin Geometry, provides a rigorous treatment of differential operators on manifolds and their analytical framework. Beginning with fundamental concepts—including order classification, principal symbols, and formal adjoints—it illustrates the theory through geometric examples like gradient, divergence, and Laplace operators. The course then develops Sobolev space theory, covering norms, embedding theorems, compactness results, and weak solution regularity, forming the analytical foundation for Hodge theory and spectral analysis of elliptic operators.



Video 2025-08-02



/




Spin Geometry (Christian Bär)

title: Aug 02, 2025
text:

This lecture, based on Chapter 1 of Christian Bär’s Spin Geometry, provides a rigorous treatment of differential operators on manifolds and their analytical framework. title: Jul 12, 2025
text:
Xingyu Chen, Chen Wei


WKB Method and Symplectic Geometry



This lecture first presents a clear physical image of the motivation behind the WKB approximation and its application methods from the perspective of perturbation of action, which is commonly used in physics. Later, based on the reference book “Lectures on the geometry of quantization”, we introduces symplectic manifolds—smooth manifolds equipped with a closed, nondegenerate 2-form—as the natural setting for Hamiltonian mechanics. Starting from linear symplectic geometry, we develop key concepts like Lagrangian subspaces and the canonical symplectic structure on cotangent bundles. These ideas provide a coordinate-free framework for classical dynamics and prepare the ground for geometric quantization.



Video 2025-07-12



/




Lectures on the Geometry of Quantization (Sean Bates, Alan Weinstein)

title: Jul 12, 2025
text:

Later, based on the reference book “Lectures on the geometry of quantization”, we introduces symplectic manifolds—smooth manifolds equipped with a closed, nondegenerate 2-form—as the natural setting for Hamiltonian mechanics. title: Mar 29, 2025
text:
Yiyi Wan


Chiral Anomaly



We began by reviewing the derivation of Noether’s theorem in classical field theory, and then introduced the Ward identity in the context of quantum field theory. Using the example of a massless Dirac fermion, we investigated the emergence of the chiral anomaly and analyzed the breaking of axial symmetry, leading to a non-vanishing divergence of the conserved current. This phenomenon is then connected to the Atiyah–Singer index theorem, allowing us to compute the partition function on a compact 4d manifold without gravity. Finally, we applied the generalized Atiyah–Patodi–Singer index theorem to extend our conclusions to the case of 3+1d topological insulators.



Video 2025-03-29



Notes 2025-03-29




Gauge Theory (David Tong)
Topological Field Theory of Time-Reversal Invariant Insulators (Xiao-Liang Qi, Taylor Hughes and Shou-Cheng Zhang)

title: Jun 07, 2025
text:
Ran Luo


SymTFT



In this talk, we first introduced the general principles of Symmetry Topological Field Theory (SymTFT), from which its possible forms can be derived. We then presented two complementary descriptions of SymTFT: one based on Lagrangian topological field theories and the other in categorical language. The appropriate contexts and advantages of each formulation were discussed, with a simple example involving a \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) 0-form symmetry used to illustrate both approaches in detail. Finally, we explored an application of SymTFT to phase classification via categorical Landau paradigms, highlighting its advancement over traditional Landau theory in systematically classifying symmetry-protected topological (SPT) and symmetry-enriched topological (SET) phases.



Video 2025-06-07



Notes 2025-06-07



/

title: Mar 15, 2025
text:
Ran Luo


Axiomatic Construction of TQFT



In this session, we began by exploring the boundaries in topological quantum field theory (TQFT), followed by a review of the notion of quantum anomalies and their implications. We then discussed how invariants can be described in a more axiomatic framework. The session continued with an investigation into boundary invariants and spin structures.



Video 2025-03-15



Notes 2025-03-15




Topological Quantum Field Theory (M. Atiyah)

title: Jun 15, 2025
text:
Xingyang Yu


Non-invertible Symmetries in 4d



This talk reviewed the historical development of non-invertible symmetries in two-dimensional field theories, especially in conformal field theory, and discussed their connection to anomaly matching under the renormalization group flow in more general settings. We then introduced recent progress on non-invertible symmetries in four-dimensional quantum field theories. In particular, we presented how two distinct types of anomalies—the Adler–Bell–Jackiw (ABJ) anomaly and the ’t Hooft anomaly—can each give rise to nontrivial non-invertible symmetries.



Video 2025-06-15



Notes 2025-06-15




Kramers-Wannier-like duality defects in (3 + 1)d gauge theories (Justin Kaidi, Kantaro Ohmori, Yunqin Zheng)
Non-invertible Global Symmetries in the Standard Model (Yichul Choi, Ho Tat Lam, and Shu-Heng Shao)

We then introduced recent progress on non-invertible symmetries in four-dimensional quantum field theories. In particular, we presented how two distinct types of anomalies—the Adler–Bell–Jackiw (ABJ) anomaly and the ’t Hooft anomaly—can each give rise to nontrivial non-invertible symmetries.

title: May 17, 2025
text:
Ran Luo


SPT Construction



We began by introducing the Lieb-Robinson bound, which provides estimates on the correlations between local operators in lattice systems, thereby motivating the notion of a causal light cone on the lattice. We then defined quasi-local unitary operators and discussed their implementation complexity in terms of quantum circuits. Building on these concepts, we explored the definition of symmetry-protected topological (SPT) phases, characterized by whether each quantum gate respects the underlying symmetry. Finally, we examined the cluster chain model as a concrete example of an SPT phase, analyzed its decorated domain-wall structure, and connected it to projective representations, thereby establishing a classification scheme for bosonic SPT phases.



Video 2025-05-17



Notes 2025-05-17

title: May 17, 2025
text:
Ran Luo


SPT Construction



We began by introducing the Lieb-Robinson bound, which provides estimates on the correlations between local operators in lattice systems, thereby motivating the notion of a causal light cone on the lattice. We then defined quasi-local unitary operators and discussed their implementation complexity in terms of quantum circuits. Building on these concepts, we explored the definition of symmetry-protected topological (SPT) phases, characterized by whether each quantum gate respects the underlying symmetry. Finally, we examined the cluster chain model as a concrete example of an SPT phase, analyzed its decorated domain-wall structure, and connected it to projective representations, thereby establishing a classification scheme for bosonic SPT phases.

title: Apr 19, 2025
text:
Xianfeng Jiang


Chern-Weil Theorem



We began by reviewing the theory of de Rham cohomology and then introduced the notions of super vector spaces and super algebras. Building on the natural \(\mathbb{Z}_2\)-grading of these structures, we extended the concept to vector bundles over manifolds, leading to the definitions of super vector bundles and super algebras of sections, along with their basic properties. We then generalized the classical notion of a connection on a vector bundle to the \(\mathbb{Z}_2\)-graded setting via the Quillen superconnection. Within this framework, we presented and proved the Chern–Weil theorem for characteristic classes. Super vector bundles and their connections serve as a foundational tool in the study of the Atiyah–Singer Index Theorem.

title: Apr 19, 2025
text:
Speaker 2
Yiyi Wan

Theme
Characteristic Classes


Abstract
In this lecture, we began with a brief review of how characteristic classes can be defined via invariant polynomials. We then introduced several common types of characteristic classes, including the Chern class, Todd class, Pontryagin class, and Euler class, highlighting their key properties. Following that, we presented the most general form of the Atiyah–Singer Index Theorem and explained its broad applications in physics. In particular, by introducing the \(\hat{A}-genus\) (A-roof genus), we gained a deeper understanding of how the index theorem manifests in the case of the Dirac operator.
